716710f-a.title: Manhattan: Bleecker Street - 7th Avenue South
716710f-a.text:
No's. 303, 305-7 &. 309 Bleecker Street, northeast side, between Seventh Avenue South and Grove Street, showing two antiquated structures and a tin garage (No. 303). The individual photo is of No. 309, the house in which Thomas Paine resided from July 1808, to April 1809. At this time this thoroughfare was known as Herring Street.
No's. 1-2-3:May 27, 1930
P. L. Sperr
716710f-a.folder: Bleecker Street & 7th Avenue South, Manhattan, NY

709603f-a.title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue South - Bleecker Street
709603f-a.text:
Seventh Avenue South, adjoining and at the S.E. corner of Bleecker Street, the former S.W. corner of Bleecker and Commerce Streets, showing the rear of 286 and 284 (old Nos. 270 and 268) Bleecker Street, the former slightly truncated by the avenue. These are frame houses faced with brick. Nos. 287 and 285, on the north side of Bleecker Street, are also shown. Nos. 289 and 283 are almost entirely off the
picture or hidden.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
709603f-a.folder: 7th Avenue South & Bleecker Street, Manhattan, NY

716706f-a.text:
Bleecker Street, north from and including Seventh Avenue South, seen from the eastern end of Commerce Street. At the left, across Seventh Avenue South, is the former N.W. corner of Barrow and BBleecler Streets, the only one of the four corners left intact when

709616f-a.title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - Barrow Street
709616f-a.text:
Seventh Avenue, (left: at tne N. E. corner of Barrow Street (right) showing a gas station which formerly occupied property belonging to two separate owners. Because of difficulties the tenant was dispossed from the corner plot and the owner had same fenced in. A story giving details was recently carried in
either the New York Sun or Times.
View 2 is another angle of samue scene.
September 16, 1938
Views 1 and 2
George  . Chinn  NO RRCPRDOUCTIONS

716705f-c.title: Manhattan: Bleecker Street - 7th Avenue South
716705f-c.text:
Bleecker Street, northeast side, north from Seventh Avenue South. The aged buildings appearing in the foreground are No's. 305-7 (a double house) and 309. The latter is the Thomas Paine home of 1808-9. At that date this thoroughfare was known as Herring Street and had just been opened. View No. 2 is slightly earlier and shows the tin garage (No. 303) used as atea room. No. 3 is still earlier and is in the opposite direction being photographed
from a point above Grove Street.
No. 1: Sept. 26, 1928
2: March 28, 1928
3: Oct. 14, 1927
P. L. Sperr
716705f-c.folder: Bleecker Street & 7th Avenue South, Manhattan, NY

716707f-a.title: Manhattan: Bleecker Street - 7th Avenue South
716707f-a.text:
Bleecker Street, northeast side, north from Seventh Avenue South, across Grove, to Christopher Street's. The two blocks shown are the last of the section that passed thru the former Herring Farm, and was called Herring Street. The triangular block in the foreground exists since the cutting thru of Seventh Avenue in 1915. Antiquated attic structures seen are No's. 305-7 &. 309. The latter, formerly No. 293, is the house in which Thomas Paine lived from July, 1808, to April, 1809. At this time Herring Street was newly opened. View No. 2 is of the Doll's House Tea Room located in the tin shack at the apex. Anna Mescia of Grantwood is the property owner and will commission S. Schuman, architect, to design a two story dwelling and store for this site. This is to cost'12,000 as reported in the New York
Times of April 27, 1939.
No. 1: 1922
2: Sept. 26, 1928
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
P. L. Sperr
716707f-a.folder: Bleecker Street & 7th Avenue South, Manhattan, NY

Bleecker Street, northeast side, north from Seventh Avenue South, across Grove, to Christopher Street's. The two blocks shown are the last of the section that passed thru the former Herring Farm, and was called Herring Street. The triangular block in the foreground exists since the cutting thru of Seventh Avenue in 1915. Antiquated attic structures seen are No's. 305-7 &. 309. The latter, formerly No. 293, is the house in which Thomas Paine lived from July, 1808, to April, 1809. At this time Herring Street was newly opened. View No. 2 is of the Doll's House Tea Room located in the tin shack at the apex. Anna Mescia of Grantwood is the property owner and will commission S. Schuman, architect, to design a two story dwelling and store for this site. This is to cost'12,000 as reported in the New York

719164f-b.title: Manhattan: Commerce Street - 7th Avenue
719164f-b.text:
(1)
Commerce Street, south side, west from Seventh Ave., and across Bedford Street. This street at the far end makes a right angle bend northward, to terminate at Barrow Street. The 2-story structures with the dormer windows are frame buildings and are separated by a
4-story tenement, that was formerly a factory.
May 19, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, in the opposite direction (eastward) as seen from a point weat of Bedford Street and showing a 2c-story frame house at the S.W. corner of Bedford and Commerce Streets. This building
bears No. 77 gedford Street.
May 27, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
